data.title: Wednesday, 31 July 2019 4:44 pm Darwins expressions of emotion:  Theory
data.meta_description: Lecture notes - mini for lectures 1-11 emotions wednesday, 31 july 2019 4:44 pm darwins expressions of emotion: theory of evolution  natural selection
data.text:
Emotions -

Wednesday, 31 July 2019

4:44 pm

Darwins expressions of emotion:



Theory of evolution by natural selection



Expressions occur with actions: survive



Actions induced by mind: serviceable associated habits



Principle of antithesis

Darwin's research methods:



Observing earlier stages of human development

o Infants, insane people



Non-europeans (savages)

o Examine similarities in emotional expressions between races



Questionnaires to missionaries



Photos of expressions

Experience of emotions:



Common sense of emotions is wrong

o Usual emotions are wrong



Bodily changes happen before the emotion



Visceral change or change in expressive behaviours

o Increase in sympathetic nervous system

o Fight response

James and Darwin



Similarity: its an adaptive function

o Contribute to the survival of us

o James: nervous system

o Darwin: emotions



Darwin focuses on the expression of emotion whereas James focused on the experience of

emotion



James argued you could only experience emotions when you express the bodily changes

James' methods:



Introspection

o To help prove his theory was right



Studied two kinds of pathologies

o Unmotivated emotions



Fear attacks without cause for experiencing the fear, clear evidence of

theory



Fear was caused by the bodily changes

o Inability to experience bodily feelings



Anathestic still experienced emotions



Behaviourism

o Learning and situational determinants of behaviour

o Stanley charter

Two factor theory of emotion



Physiological arousal

o Feedback from autonomic nervous system



Situationally - appropriate cognition

o Arousal and cognition is the emotion



Need to explain their arousal

o Bodily changes is necessary to emotion

o Cognition is necessary for explanation

Cognition of Emotion

Friday, 9 August 2019

10:44 am

Magda Arnold



Understanding emotions = understanding how we judge situations



Criticises James' approach: perception > bodily changes = emotions



Arnold: perception > judgement-harm/benefit = emotion



Appraisals: quick, immediate, non-intellectual

o Quick judgements of a situation



Emotion: impulse to action = adaptive



Physiological responses: unpleasant tensions



Every emotion: own pattern physiological activity because different emotions > different

actions

Richard Lazarus



Appraisals: whether situation is good or bad, depends on personal goals etc



Cognitive-motivational-relational

o Goals, expectations, intentions



Two levels: molecular and molar > combine the appraisals into core relational themes

Ira Roseman



Each emotion has their own unique cognitive structure



Five set of appraisals: 14 emotions

Consistent with motives

a. Inconsistent (negative) vice/versa

Certain or uncertain

Responsibility: self-other-situationally

Reward (appetitive) or punishment (aversive)

Oneself: weak or strong

Social influences on the emotional process



Nature of emotions: our emotions affect others AND other persons influence our emotions

over and above the emotional stimulus itself



Theoretical framework:

o Assumption: others have an impact on emotions because emotions are often

directed at others

Shame motivates self improvement which leads to social improvement

Differences between emotion, mood and affect

Emotion: state-trait distinction, focus on state

Mood: no object or a very general object

Affect: broad definition; mood, emotions, pleasure likes

Domains - How emotions play out



Subjective experiences or feelings



Physiological reactions



Behavioural reactions



Cognition

o Thought that someone harmed you deliberately



Expressive reactions

o Smiles



Serve functions

o To help motivate reactions and improvements



Different methods of measurement

Scenarios based on definitions



Guilt: arises from harming someone else



Regret: results from harm to yourself



Thus guilt and regret are conceptually related; they deal with harm doing but differ with

regard to the target of harm



The difference is crucial for writing scenarios

Designing scenarios for related/different emotions

Similarities and differences

a. Both are related to harm

Elaborate on differences

a. Regret is to harm oneself > varied as the function of the negative consequences as

evaluated by oneself

b. Guilt is only to harm someone else

Social context: other people can affect our emotions

a. Guilt is affect by the reaction of others

Scenarios should not cover both emotions



Avoid emotion words in scenarios



Imagine the situation as vividly as you can, which you can do by going step by step through

the described situation

Measuring emotions



Usually rating scales are used to help assess the situation

Perspective taking

Friday, 30 August 2019

10:59 am

Stolen Generations



100,000 aboriginals were removed from their homes and placed in the homes of white

Australians



Ongoing emotional problems involved in the institutions



HREOC: apology and monetary compensation



False beliefs: economic advantages

o Indigenous people get free house, cars and special treatment

o Prejudicial treatment of aboriginals

o Evoked angers towards them

Perspective taking



Empathy based: experience

o Imagine the experience of the person

o Helps reduce prejudice



Perspective taking: being the other person

o Negative stereotypes about elderly people



Difference in focus

Social identity theory



Self-esteem: personal identity and memberships social groups: social identity.



PT: expand self-esteem to other

Schadenfreude:



First studied from tall poppies to later study, deservingness and schadenfreude

Tall Poppy



Person with high status



Celebrity, politician etc



Certain satisfaction when these people reverse and get pulled down a peg

Schadenfreude



When the feeling of seeing someone suffer, fall or be brought down gives us pleasure

Deservingness



Entitlement is legal principles rather than outcomes that are always positive

o Not negative outcomes

Positive or negative actions lead to positive or negative outcomes.



4 possibilities

Positive action that leads to a positive outcome is balanced, as it is supposed to happen.

Negative action that leads to negative outcome is deserved. Balanced.

Positive outcome leads to negative outcome, unbalanced.

Negative outcome leads to positive outcome: unbalanced and undeserved.

Social Identity

Friday, 6 September 2019

Why group emotions?



Group emotions help us to understand the world around us

o They are specific

o Immediate/automatic

o They communicate more than cold cognitive statements



Prejudice - overt and subtle



Harm of outgroups



Competition and conflict



Intergroup reconcilliation and peace



Protest and political action tendencies



Intergroup helping and acts of solidarity

Explaining intergroup hositility



When will an ingroup, move against an outgroup? (fight) When will group members 'walk

away' from conflictual intergroup setting (flight)?



Fight or flight is a function of a group based emotions which are, themselves, a function of

situationally-relevant appraisals



Group strength

o Coping ability - secondary appraisal



Should homosexual couples in long term-relationships have the right to marry?

o Supports or opposed



Experimental test manipulated extent to which ingroup is:

o Strong - 16 newspaper headlines (support)

o Weak - 16 newspapers headlines (opposition)

o Control - no information



Measured:

o Identification with the ingroup



Emotions of anger and fear

o Actions



Confront, oppose or attack

o Defensive intergroup actions (avoid, have nothing to do with them, keep them at

distance)

Fight or flight is a function of group based emotions which are, themselves, a function of

situationally relevant appraisals



How low and high identifiers would appraise the situation differently in situations of threat

o Secondary appraisal

Relative depravation and resource

mobilisation

Thursday, 12 September 2019

11:55 am

Aims



Provide an overview of theory and research into two key psychological responses to injustice

and inequality

o Relative deprivation

o Collective action

Relative deprivation



Arises from the perception that you are worse off compared to other people or groups

Three components



Social comparison - compare yourself to another



Appraisal - appraises that he/she is disadvantaged relative to that other group



Illegiticimacy - the disadvantage is perceived as illegitimate and unfair

Arises from a subjective evaluation



Structurally advantaged people can experience relative deprivation

Distinction between individual deprivation (called egoistic) and group based deprivation (called

fraternal)



Individual deprivation based on interpersonal social comparisons (s/he has more than me)



Group deprivation based on intergroup social comparisons



Fit between the level and the outcome

Collective action

Relative deprivation is a strong predictor of collective action



It makes people angry



Difference between perceiving an inequality and feeling an inequality

Group based anger



Anger based on group membership



Invokes specific action tendencies to confront those responsible



State of action readiness

A meta-analysis showed that anger is a better predictor of engagement in collective action than

perceptions of injustice

Social identifiation



That part of an individuals self concept which derives from his of her knowledge of

membership to a social group (or groups) together with the value and emotional significance

attached to it

Klandermans (2002)



Collective action presents a social dilemma:

o Based on pure rationality (cost-benefit), individuals would take a 'free ride'



The more someone identifies with a group, the more likely it is that s/he will participate in

protest if they feel that the group is being treated unjustly



Social identification helps us to 'overcome the dilemma of collective action'

o The group is self

o Fosters an inner-obligation

What kind of social identity?



Politicised identities

o Group members engage as a mindful and self-conscious collective in a power

struggle knowing that it is the wider, more inclusive societal context in which this

struggle takes place and needs to be orchestrated accordingly



Social identities are based on opinions about how the world should be are particularly useful

o Pro marriage

o Anti poverty

o Pro-reconcilliation

o Pro-animal welfare

The Social Identity Model of Collective Action

Engaging Online

Friday, 20 September 2019

10:24 am

New technologies and social change



Facilitation hypothesis



Slacktivism hypothesis

Kony 2012



Campaign to end the activities of Joseph Kony

o Generate political will to capture him



Support for the video, participate in an event called cover the night

One of the worlds fastest growing internet phenomena



100 million downloads



50% of young American adults had heard about Kony2012 in the days following the release



The offline campaign attracted a low level of support



Slacktivism pointed out Kony2012 as another failure of online action

Workshop Part

Enaging online is a valid, meaningful expression of social identities based on opinions about how we

want the world to be



Not disconnected or part of a personal, self promoting agenda

Engaging online reflects a desire to enhance the groups interests

Conventional, political collective action:



Action that conforms to the norms of the existing social system, such as political

participation or peaceful protest

Extreme, radical collective action



Action that violates the rules of the exisiting social system, such as unlawful behaviour,

violence and at its most extreme - terrorism

Online forms of civic engagement/participation are 'slack', meaningless and trivial



But

Online radicalisation is a real threat

Pathways to engagement and extremism



Engagement and extremism are processes

o Politicisation



Increasing awareness that a given issue/problem is embedded in a system of

unequal power relation

o Radicalisation



A change in beliefs, feelings and behaviours in directions that increasingly

justify intergroup violence and demand sacrifice in defense of the ingroup

o The 'ends justify the means'

Mobilisation through social interaction



Through discussion and debate people can develop and reach consensus about who we are

and what we do



Social interaction is a driver of 'grassroots' (bottom up) social identity formation

Extremism



Political violence literature

o Analysis of web content showed how group members can radicalise through online

interaction

Social interaction can contribute to both political engagement and extremism

Radicalisation can emerge from social interaction in context



Combination of inter and intra group factors



Interaction is not inevitably linked to extremism

Politicisation and radicalisation can be understood as a social process or pathway



Not a product of specific social conditions in certain societies or religious groups, nor an

aspect of psychopathology

Extremism

Friday, 20 September 2019

11:05 am

How can we understand the drivers of diverging forms of collective action?



Lots of different terms

o Moderate v militant

o Normative v non-normative

o Activism v radicalism

o Political v radical

o Within system v out-of-system

Conventional, political action:



Action that conforms to the norms of the existing social system, such as political

participation or peaceful protest

Extreme, radical collective action:



Action that violates the rules of the existing social system, such as unlawful behaviour,

violence and at its most - terrorism

Understanding radical action



The relations between emotional reactions to injustice, efficacy and action differs for more

extreme, radical (non-normative) forms of collective action.

Emotional pathway



Anger predicts engagement in conventional, political actions

o Anger is a constructive emotion



Contempt predicts engagement in extreme, radical (non-normative) forms of collective

action

o Contempt is associated with derogation of social relationships and social exclusion

o Leads to a physical and psychological distancing

Efficacy pathway



Group efficacy predicts engagement in conventional, political (normative) actions



A lack of efficacy predicts engagement in extreme, radical (non-normative) forms of

collective action

o Individuals feel that their group is powerless to address an injustice

o Nothing to lose

Distributive justice and entitlement

Sunday, 13 October 2019

5:30 pm

The perspective of psychology



Subjective perceptions of justice

o How they respond to experiences of justice

Three areas of justice:



Distributive justice

Multi-principle approaches



Assumption of several distinct justice principles

o Contribution (equity) principle



Should be based on input/contribution, shared resources or benefits

o Equality principle



Should ignore any differentiating outcomes, and should share it

o Need principle



Should be based on need



Appropriateness depends on the social construction of the situation



Deutsch (1975) - value orientation

o Economical orientation (productivity): equity

o Solidarity orientation (relationships): equality

o Care orientation (welfare of others): need

Normative and instrumental reasons for adoption of principle



Definition of situation requires certain principles



Apply principle to define situation in a certain way

Implications



Relative to equity theory less individualistic: a more social conception of justice

o Justice exisits and has a normative power distinct from concerns about (immediate)

self interest

o There are multiple notions of justice

o Their normativeness/relevance depends on the situation

o Understanding of justice shared when social construction of the situation is shared

Belief in a Just World

Sunday, 13 October 2019

6:03 pm

Normal people will reject, or devalue an innocent victim, if they are not able to intervene effectively

to correct the injustice.

Belief in a just world theory



People generally need to believe that the world is a just place where people get what they

deserve



This is the basis of their justice motive, the motivation to maintain justice and fairness

o Through



Rational strategies Non-rational strategies Protective strategies

Prevention

Restitution

Blaming the victim

Derogating the victim

Reinterpreting outcomes

Denial/withdrawal

Belief in ultimate justice

Just and unjust words

Why do people need to believe in a just world?



A personal contract

o When children to delay gratifications

o Personal contract requires that the world is just: people get what they deserve

o BJW is part of humans' long-term goal-orientated behaviour

o But becomes value in itself (impartial commitment to justice)

Long term goal orientation



Participants focused on long term goals



Blamed, derogated and disassociated from an innocent victim (but not a non-innocent

victim)

Responses to own suffering



Would people similarly protect their BJW when they are the victim?

o Bulman and Wortman interviews with paraplegic victims of accidents



Rather than avoiding blame, Ps attributed more blame to themselves than

the objective circumstances would warrant



The more victimes blamed themselves for the accident, the better their

subsequent adjustment (as rated by nurses and social workers)

o Is self blame always adaptive?

BJW as a personal resource?



Dalbert: BJW as a personal resource

o Helps to maintain and foster a sense of well-being, specifically in the face of

negative-life events

o Conceptualised and measured as an individual difference variable



Buffered against anger and self-esteem loss when recalling an anger provoking experience

(injustice)



Why should people high in BJW manage their anger and maintain their health better?

Procedural Justice and Legitimacy

Tuesday, 15 October 2019

2:12 pm

Procedural justice



How do people want to see their disputes resolved?

o When would people turn to third parties?

Disputes in legal contexts: inquisitorial vs adversarial systems.

Objective accuracy and subjective fairness



In group charged with stealing ideas from other teams

o Hearing: inquisitorial v adversarial procedure

o Verdict: innocent v guilty

Extending the concept



Leventhal (1980)

o Consistency

o Bias suppression

o Accuracy of information

o Correctability

Instrumental v relational perspectives



Instrumental concerns: legitimacy attributions based on favourability of outcomes and

decisions

Relational concerns- legitimacy attributuons based on the relationship and identity communicated

through authorities/system



Procedural justice, in decision-making and treatment

o Communicates respect and standing within group

o Provides basis for pride and identification with group



Positive social identity

Legitimacy beyond compliance



Compliance: willingness to obey the rules, to accept decisions Obligation



Cooperation: volunteering efforts to work with and support the authority Trust and

Confidence



Community engagement: conducting ones own initiatives and working alongside the

authority to advance shared goals and values Normative alignment

Moral conviction

= the strong belief that certain outcomes, certain duties or rights derive from a higher moral

purpose, from fundamentals of right and wrong



May trump procedural fairness of decision making in determining decision acceptance



And may also affect legitimacy perceptions

Retributive Justice

Friday, 18 October 2019

2:06 pm

Restoration of justice after wrongdoing



It implies holding someone accountable for the injustice



See punishment

Compensation and punishment



Compensation is the repair of harm/injustice caused by trangression

o Restitution (undone)

o Reparation (equivalent payment)



Punishment: suffering or costs imposed on the offender in addition to

compensation, in response to the wrongdoing itself.

o Retributive justice in a narrow sense: a principle of justice restoration

through the imposition of punishment on the offender in proportion to the moral

severity of their wrongdoing

Attribution of responsibility and blame



Darley and pittman (2003)

o Unintentional harm leads to compensation

o Intentional is punishment

o Negligent: may vary between compensation and punishment



Attributions of responsibility are key determinants, mediated by moral outrage

o Intention = moral outrage = retribution

Punishment and revenge



A matter of perspective

o Revenge: punitive punishment by the victim

o Punishment: punitive response by a third-party authority

Punishment goals:



Justice (just desert, retributivism): backward looking, restoring a moral balance



Behaviour control (utalitarinaism) forward looking, prevention of future occurences

o Specific detterence

o General deterrence

o Incapacitation

o Rehabilitation

Behaviour control vs justice



People don’t have insight into their true punishment motives



Behavioural process tracing method

Why the urge to punish?

Does it make us feel better?



De Quervain et al. (2004): brain regions activated during decision to punish a

wrongdoer (the dorsal striatum), involved the processing of rewards



Carlsmith, Wilson, & Gilbert (2008): participants wrongly anticipate to feel better

after punishing wrong-doer, they actually feel worse



Gollwitzer & Bushman (2012): “frozen-mood pills” and “good-mood rooms” with no

effect on willingness to punish

. Do we merely want to see the offender suffer?



Imagine an offence against you ... and then the offender has bad luck and loses

money by fate, or you are in the position to impose a loss on the offender:

Would you feel equally satisfied?



Gollwitzer et al. (2011): it depends on whether the offender recognises the imposed

suffering as a punishment for their wrongdoing – if so, imposition is more satisfying

>>> communicative function of punishment (Funk et al., 2014)

Retributive and restorative justice



Retributive justice: justice through imposition of punishment

o Punishment per se: no moral transformation (acceptance or remorse) of

offender required



Restorative justice: justice through consensus between parties

o Punishment may be part of the process if parties agree on it as a measure

When do people endorse which notion of justice?

Symbolic implications of trangressions
